title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
üéØ Learning Objective
Derive individual demand curves from utility maximization theory
Our Example: Two goods - üç∫ Rum (x-axis) - ‚öîÔ∏è Swords (y-axis)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
üéØ Learning Objective
Derive individual demand curves from utility maximization theory
Our Example: Two goods - üç∫ Rum (x-axis) - ‚öîÔ∏è Swords (y-axis)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
The Budget Constraint

Basic Setup
Consumer income: \(M\) to spend on two goods: - Rum (\(R\)) with price \(p_R\) - Swords (\(S\)) with price \(p_S\)


Budget Constraint Equation
\[p_R \cdot R + p_S \cdot S = M\]


Slope-Intercept Form
\[S = \frac{M}{p_S} - \frac{p_R}{p_S} \cdot R\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Initial Scenario

Our Assumptions

Income: \(M = \$120\)
Price of Rum: \(p_R = \$4\) per bottle

Price of Swords: \(p_S = \$6\) per sword



Initial Budget Constraint
\[4R + 6S = 120\]


Slope-Intercept Form
\[S = 20 - \frac{2}{3}R\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Utility Function

Cobb-Douglas Utility Function
\[U(R,S) = R^{0.6} \cdot S^{0.4}\]
Why Cobb-Douglas? - Mathematically tractable - Realistic diminishing marginal utility - Widely used in economics
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Utility Maximization

The Key Condition
Marginal Rate of Substitution = Price Ratio
\[MRS_{R,S} = \frac{MU_R}{MU_S} = \frac{p_R}{p_S}\]


For Cobb-Douglas Function

\(MU_R = 0.6 \cdot R^{-0.4} \cdot S^{0.4}\)
\(MU_S = 0.4 \cdot R^{0.6} \cdot S^{-0.6}\)



Therefore:
\[MRS_{R,S} = 1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R}\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Finding the Optimal Bundle

Setting MRS = Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{4}{6} = \frac{2}{3}\]


Solving for S in terms of R
\[S = \frac{4}{9}R\]


Substituting into Budget Constraint
\[4R + 6 \cdot \frac{4}{9}R = 120\]


Result: \((R^*, S^*) = (18, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $3

New Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{3}{6} = \frac{1}{2}\]


New Relationship
\[S = \frac{1}{3}R\]


New Budget Constraint
\[3R + 6S = 120\]


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (24, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $6

New Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{6}{6} = 1\]


New Relationship
\[S = \frac{2}{3}R\]


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (12, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $2

Following the same process‚Ä¶


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (36, 8)\)
Notice: Swords consumption stays constant at 8!
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Demand Schedule



Price of Rum
Quantity of Rum
Quantity of Swords
Total Utility




$6
12 bottles
8 swords
57.9


$4
18 bottles
8 swords
67.2


$3
24 bottles
8 swords
73.8


$2
36 bottles
8 swords
85.7
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Mathematical Demand Function

General Cobb-Douglas Result
For \(a = 0.6, b = 0.4, M = 120, p_S = 6\):


Rum Demand Function:
\[R^*(p_R) = \frac{72}{p_R}\]


Swords Demand Function:
\[S^* = 8\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Key Economic Insights

üìä Elasticity Analysis
For demand function \(R = \frac{72}{p_R}\):
\[\varepsilon_{R,p_R} = -1\]
Unit Elastic Demand at all points!


üí° Income and Substitution Effects
When price decreases from $4 to $3: - Total Effect: \(\Delta R = 24 - 18 = 6\) bottles - Both effects reinforce the law of demand
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:

crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Key Takeaways

‚úÖ What We Learned

Budget constraints limit consumer choices
Utility maximization determines optimal bundles

Price changes create predictable demand responses
Mathematical functions can be derived analytically
Elasticity provides insights into behavior



üéØ The Framework
Essential tools for economic analysis and policy evaluation
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Questions?

ü§î Discussion Topics

What happens with different utility function parameters?
How do income changes affect demand?
What about substitute and complement goods?



üìö Next Steps

Practice with problem sets
Explore interactive simulations
Apply to real-world examples
